00010 /**
00011 
00012 @page ptp 1588 Precision Time Protocol
00013 
00014 @section ptp_intro 1. Introduction
00015 
00016 The Cavium Inc. implementation of the IEEE1588 specification for
00017 Precision Time Protocol (PTP) supports all OCTEON models.  The
00018 implementation uses hardware timestamps available in OCTEON II for
00019 better accuracy, or reverts to software timestamps on OCTEON and
00020 OCTEON Plus chips.  Throughout this document and the source code, the
00021 IEEE1588 specifications are called out to help reference where
00022 concepts and data are directly dictated by the specification.  These
00023 generally refer to a specific section number in the IEEE
00024 specification.
00025 
00026     - @ref ptp_intro
00027     - @ref ptp_version
00028     - @ref ptp_version2
00029         - @ref ptp_sync
00030         - @ref ptp_unicast
00031         - @ref ptp_management
00032         - @ref ptp_accuracy
00033         - @ref ptp_usage
00034         - @ref ptp_daemon
00035     - @ref ptp_version1
00036 
00037 @section ptp_version 2. Protocol Versions
00038 
00039 The IEEE 1588 specification has two major versions, 2004 and 2008.
00040 The version from 2004 is commonly referred to as PTPv1, while 2008 is
00041 referred to as PTPv2.  Unfortunately the two standards do not
00042 interoperate directly, so most systems choose only one for use in a
00043 complete synchronization system.  PTPv2 defines an optional
00044 translation compatibility for allowing PTPv1 clocks to synchronize
00045 with PTPv2 clocks in IEEE1588-2008 section 18.  Cavium Inc.
00046 implementation of the two standards can be found in @ref ptp_version2
00047 and @ref ptp_version1.
00048 
00049 @section ptp_version2 3. PTPv2 - IEEE 1588-2008
00050 
00051 Sections from the specification that are implemented:
00052     - Sections 1-4 - Informative only
00053     - Section 5 - Data types and on-the-wire formats in a PTP system.
00054     - Section 6 - Clock synchronization model
00055         - Sections 6.1 through 6.4
00056         - Section 6.5.1 - General
00057         - Section 6.5.2 - Ordinary clocks
00058         - Section 6.5.3 - Boundary clocks
00059         - Section 6.5.6 - Management nodes
00060         - Sections 6.6 and 6.7
00061     - Section 7 - Characterization of PTP entities
00062     - Section 8 - PTP data sets
00063         - Section 8.1 - General specifications for data set members
00064         - Section 8.2 - Data sets for ordinary and boundary clocks
00065     - Section 9 - PTP for ordinary and boundary clocks.
00066     - Section 11 - Clock offset, path delay, residence time, and asymmetry corrections.
00067     - Section 12 - Synchronization and syntonization of clocks.
00068     - Section 13 - PTP message formats.
00069     - Section 14 - TLV entity specifications
00070     - Section 15 - Management
00071     - Section 16 - General optional features
00072         - Section 16.1 - Unicast message negotiation.
00073         - Section 16.2 - Path trace.
00074     - Section 17 - State configuration options.
00075     - Annex D - Transport of PTP over User Datagram Protocol over Internet Protocol Version 4
00076     - Annex E - Transport of PTP over User Datagram Protocol over Internet Protocol Version 6
00077     - Annex F - Transport of PTP over IEEE 802.3 / Ethernet.
00078 
00079 Optional Features from IEEE1588-2008 that are not supported:
00080 
00081     - Section 6 - Clock synchronization model
00082         - Section 6.5.4 - End-to-end transparent clocks
00083         - Section 6.5.5 - Peer-to-peer transparent clocks
00084     - Section 8 - PTP data sets
00085         - Section 8.3 - Data sets for transparent clocks
00086     - Section 10 - PTP for transparent clocks
00087     - Section 16 - General optional features
00088         - Section 16.3 - Alternate timescales.
00089     - Section 18 - Compatibility requirements.
00090     - Section 19 - Conformance
00091     - Annex A-C - Informative only
00092     - Annex G-J
00093     - Annex K-M - Informative only
00094 
00095 @subsection ptp_sync 3.1. Synchronization Model
00096 
00097 In order to synchronize a slave clock with a master, three
00098 calculations must be performed to characterize the differences between
00099 the two clocks.  First the network delay between the clocks must be
00100 measured.  Second the slave must calculate its clock tick rate in
00101 comparison to the master.  Finally the slave must measure its clock's
00102 time with respect to the absolute value of the master clock.  Each of
00103 these calculations is covered in the following sections.
00104 
00105 @subsubsection ptp_sync_delay 3.1.1 Delay Calculation
00106 
00107 PTPv2 defines two possible methods of measuring the delay between the
00108 slave and master clocks.
00109 
00110 - IEEE1588-2008 section 11.3 defines the delay request-response mechanism.
00111 - IEEE1588-2008 section 11.4 defines the peer delay request-response mechanism.
00112 
00113 <table align=center cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00114 <tr><th>Delay Mechanism</th><th>Peer Delay Mechanism</th></tr>
00115 <tr><td>
00116 @dot
00117 digraph delay
00118 {
00119     rankdir=LR;
00120     node [shape=record, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00121     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00122     master [label="Master|<s>t1|<f>|<d>t4|<r>", width=1.0];
00123     slave [label="Slave|<s>t2|<f>|<d>t3|<r>"];
00124     master:s -> slave:s [label="Sync"];
00125     master:f -> slave:f [label="Follow up"];
00126     slave:d -> master:d [label="Delay Request"];
00127     master:r -> slave:r [label="Delay Response"];
00128 }
00129 @enddot
00130 </td><td>
00131 @dot
00132 digraph pdelay
00133 {
00134     rankdir=LR;
00135     node [shape=record, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00136     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00137     master [label="Master|<p>t2|<r>t3|<f>", width=1.0];
00138     slave [label="Slave|<p>t1|<r>t4|<f>"];
00139     slave:p -> master:p [label="Peer Delay Request"];
00140     master:r -> slave:r [label="Peer Delay Response"];
00141     master:f -> slave:f [label="Peer Delay Follow up"];
00142 }
00143 @enddot
00144 </td></tr>
00145 </table>
00146 
00147 When using the delay mechanism:
00148 
00149     - t1 = Time the master sent a sync message (Master clock)
00150     - t2 = Time the slave received the sync message (Slave clock)
00151     - t3 = Time the slave sent a delay request (Slave clock)
00152     - t4 = Time the master received the delay request (Master clock)
00153     - Slave learns t1 from the follow up message
00154     - Slave learns t4 from the delay response
00155     - meanPathDelay = ((t4 - t1) - (t3 - t2)) / 2
00156 
00157 When using the peer delay mechanism:
00158 
00159     - t1 = Time the slave sent a peer delay request (Slave clock)
00160     - t2 = Time the master received the peer delay request (Master clock)
00161     - t3 = Time the master sent the peer delay response (Master clock)
00162     - t4 = Time the slave received the peer delay response (Slave clock)
00163     - Slave learns t2 from the peer delay response
00164     - Slave learns t3 from the peer delay follow up
00165     - meanPathDelay = ((t4-t1) - (t3-t2)) / 2
00166 
00167 @subsubsection ptp_sync_delay_which When to use Peer Delay versus Delay
00168 
00169 The Peer delay machanism provides better path delay calculation than
00170 the older delay mechanism, but it can only be used when both peers
00171 support the protocol.  As an example of how peer delay and normally
00172 delay messages can be used, refer to the figure below.
00173 
00174 @dot
00175 digraph delay
00176 {
00177     rankdir=LR;
00178     node [shape=circle, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00179     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica, arrowhead=none];
00180     master [label="Master"];
00181     switch1 [shape=record, label="Switch 1\n(with PTP)|<1>Port 1|<2>Port 2|<3>Port 3|<4>Port 4"];
00182     slaveA [label="Slave A"];
00183     slaveB [label="Slave B"];
00184     slaveC [label="Slave C"];
00185     switch2 [shape=record, label="Switch 2\n(without PTP)|<1>Port 1|<2>Port 2|<3>Port 3|<4>Port 4"];
00186     slaveD [label="Slave D"];
00187     slaveE [label="Slave E"];
00188     master -> switch1:1:w;
00189     switch1:2:e -> slaveA;
00190     switch1:3:e -> slaveB;
00191     switch1:4:e -> slaveC;
00192     slaveB -> switch2:1:w [style=bold];
00193     switch2:2:e -> slaveD [style=bold];
00194     slaveC -> slaveE;
00195 }
00196 @enddot
00197 
00198 In the above figure, peer delay calculations should be performed on these links:
00199 
00200 -  Switch 1 to Master
00201 - Slave A to Switch 1
00202 - Slave B to Switch 1
00203 - Slave C to Switch 1
00204 - Slave E to Slave C
00205 
00206 Less accurate delay calculations must be performed between these clocks:
00207 
00208 - Slave D to Slave B through Switch 2
00209 
00210 As synchronization messages pass through switch 1 on their way toward
00211 slaves A-C the switch will update the packet timing data.  Switch 1
00212 will change the correctionField of each message to account for the
00213 measured delay of the Master to switch link.  Switch 1 will also
00214 update Follow Up messages with the time the Sync messages took to
00215 traverse the intervals of the switch.  This allows slaves A-C to
00216 calculate their offset from Master very accurately.  Similarly Slave E
00217 will update message timing based on peer delay from slave C.  Again
00218 this will be quite accurate.
00219 
00220 When Slave D receives a message from Slave B through switch 2, it will
00221 not know how much time was spent inside of the switch.  The best
00222 estimate slave D can perform is to measure the delay through the switch to
00223 slave B and hope it is consistent.  Modern "store and forward" switches
00224 do not have constant forwarding times due to changing port load and
00225 internal processing.  Latency through these switch varies randomly
00226 in the order of a few microseconds.
00227 
00228 @subsubsection ptp_sync_rate 3.1.2 Clock Rate Synchronization
00229 
00230 <table align=center cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00231 <tr><th>Synchronization Mechanism</th></tr>
00232 <tr><td>
00233 @dot
00234 digraph delay
00235 {
00236     rankdir=LR;
00237     node [shape=record, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00238     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00239     master [label="Master|<s1>t1|<f1>||<s2>t3|<f2>", width=1.0];
00240     slave [label="Slave|<s1>t2|<f1>||<s2>t4|<f2>"];
00241     master:s1 -> slave:s1 [label="Sync (1)"];
00242     master:f1 -> slave:f1 [label="Follow up (1)"];
00243     master:s2 -> slave:s2 [label="Sync (2)"];
00244     master:f2 -> slave:f2 [label="Follow up (2)"];
00245 }
00246 @enddot
00247 </td></tr>
00248 </table>
00249 
00250 The clock ticks for the master between the two syncs is t3-t1.  The
00251 clock ticks for the slave between the two syncs is t4-t2.  If the
00252 clocks are perfectly synchronized, these two values should be
00253 identical.  If they are not identical, this represents clock drift
00254 between the master and slave.  A scale factor of (t3-t1)/(t4-t2) for
00255 the slave's clock rate would make it match the master.
00256 
00257 @subsection ptp_sync_time 3.1.3 Clock Time Synchronization
00258 
00259 <table align=center cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00260 <tr><th>Synchronization Mechanism</th></tr>
00261 <tr><td>
00262 @dot
00263 digraph delay
00264 {
00265     rankdir=LR;
00266     node [shape=record, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00267     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00268     master [label="Master|<s>t1|<f>", width=1.0];
00269     slave [label="Slave|<s>t2|<f>"];
00270     master:s -> slave:s [label="Sync"];
00271     master:f -> slave:f [label="Follow up"];
00272 }
00273 @enddot
00274 </td></tr>
00275 </table>
00276 
00277 Once the meanPathDelay has been calculated and the slave's clock rate
00278 has been synchronized with the master's clock, it is possible to
00279 figure out the slave's absolute offset from the master.
00280 
00281     - Slave learns t1 from the follow up message
00282     - offsetFromMaster = t2 - t1 - meanPathDelay
00283 
00284 If offsetFromMaster is small, the clock rate of the slave can be
00285 skewed slightly to bring it into synchronization with the master.
00286 Larger values of offsetFromMaster cause the slave to set its internal
00287 clock causing a discontinuity.
00288 
00289 @subsection ptp_unicast 3.2. Unicast versus Multicast Messages
00290 
00291 IEEE1588-2008 defines unicast message support as an optional feature.
00292 The purpose of this option is to allow clock synchronization over a
00293 WAN network where not all switches/routers in the network support PTP.
00294 The diagram below demonstrates an example system where unicast
00295 messaging would be necessary.
00296 
00297 @dot
00298 digraph delay
00299 {
00300     rankdir=LR;
00301     node [shape=circle, width=.1, height=.1, fontsize=10, font=helvitica];
00302     edge [fontsize=10, font=helvitica, arrowhead=none];
00303     master [label="Master"];
00304     switch1 [shape=record, label="Switch 1|<1>Port 1|<2>Port 2|<3>Port 3"];
00305     slaveA [label="Slave A"];
00306     slaveB [label="Slave B"];
00307     router1 [shape=record, label="Router 1|<1>Port 1|<2>Port 2"];
00308     wan [shape=none, label="WAN"];
00309     router2 [shape=record, label="Router 2|<1>Port 1|<2>Port 2"];
00310     master -> switch1:1:w;
00311     switch1:2:e -> slaveA;
00312     switch1:3:e -> router1:1:w;
00313     router1:2:e -> wan [style=bold];
00314     wan -> router2:1:w [style=bold];
00315     router2:2:e -> slaveB;
00316 }
00317 @enddot
00318 
00319 Master and Slave A will be able to communicate on the local network
00320 using multicast messages as defined in IEEE1588-2008.  Router 1 will
00321 block all messages from both Master 1 and Slave A from leaving the
00322 local network.  This leaves Slave B unable to connect to the Master's
00323 clock domain.  In order to get messages between Slave B and Master,
00324 unicast routable messages must be sent through router 1, the WAN, and
00325 router 2.  It is quite rare for routers to support the PTP protocol,
00326 so messages are forward without any latency information.  The accuracy
00327 of Slave B's clock is completely dependent on the routers and WAN have
00328 a constant delay time.  Most WANs have latencies in the range of
00329 10-100 milliseconds with random variations.  These random latencies
00330 will limit the accuracy of Slave B's clock synchronization to 10's of
00331 milliseconds.
00332 
00333 In sparse setups where network delay may change randomly, it is
00334 recommended the remote node only match clock frequency with the
00335 master.  Per the Telecom 1588 profile, nodes may choose to not
00336 calculate network delay and only use synchronization messages for
00337 frequency matching.  The OCTEON PTP 1588v2 implementation supports
00338 frequency only as well as full frequency and phase matching.
00339 
00340 @subsection ptp_management 3.3. Supported 1588v2 Signalling and Management Messages

00422 
00423 @subsection ptp_accuracy 3.4. Accuracy
00424 
00425 Using a properly configured PTP network with accurate timestamps on
00426 every hop, the OCTEON PTP 1588v2 implementation can achieve clock
00427 synchronization below 20ns, often below 10ns.  The quality and
00428 frequency of the hardware PTP clock greatly affects this accuracy.  As
00429 a general rule, clock synchronization is limited to three ticks of the
00430 PTP clock.  For example, if your PTP reference clock runs at 100Mhz,
00431 your clock synchronization will be limited to around 30ns.  Faster PTP
00432 clocks achieve better accuracy.  Sub 10ns results have been achieved
00433 using the internal 800Mhz clock generated on CN63XX.
00434 
00435 @subsection ptp_usage 3.5. System Integration and Usage
00436 
00437 The ptp1588v2 example is organized into two parts, a PTP library and a
00438 simple daemon caller.  In order to make it easy to integrate PTPv2
00439 functionality into an existing Linux based application, all
00440 PTPv2 processing is done in a library that can easily be called from
00441 any application.  The API for this library is documented in @b
00442 ptplib.h.
00443 
00444 API Functions in ptplib:
00445 
00446     - int ptplib_initialize(ptplib_state_t *ptp, ptplib_flags_t flags);
00447     - int ptplib_interface_add(ptplib_state_t *ptp, packetio_t *port);
00448     - int ptplib_process(ptplib_state_t *ptp, const packetio_packet_t *packet);
00449     - int ptplib_process_errorqueue(ptplib_state_t *ptp, const packetio_packet_t *packet);
00450     - int ptplib_periodic(ptplib_state_t *ptp);
00451     - int ptplib_display(ptplib_state_t *ptp, int clear_screen);
00452     - int ptplib_shutdown(ptplib_state_t *ptp);
00453 
00454 Configuration defines in ptplib:
00455 
00456     - USE_PTP_CLOCK
00457         - Adjust the hardware PTP counter directly instead of using
00458         the Linux system time. This greatly improves accuracy as the
00459         expense of violating the usual userspace protection
00460         mechanism. This define is set in the Makefile for
00461         ptp-1588v2 and is highly recommended.
00462     - PTP_GPIO_PPS_OUT
00463         - GPIO to use for output of a pulse signal. Default is
00464         GPIO 1. Set to -1 to disable the pulse output.
00465     - PTP_GPIO_PPS_HZ
00466         - Frequency for the PPS signal in Hertz. Default value
00467         is 1Hz, corresponding to the standard 1588 PPS signal.
00468     - PTP_GPIO_CLOCK_OUT
00469         - GPIO to use for output of a clock signal. Default is
00470         GPIO 2. Set to -1 to disable the clock output.
00471     - PTP_GPIO_CLOCK_HZ
00472         - Frequency for the clock signal in Hertz. Default value
00473         is 30.72Mhz. The phase alignment is such that the rising
00474         edge is aligned at second boundaries.
00475     - Other defines in ptplib.c
00476         - Many other parameters of the 1588v2 protocol can be
00477         adjusted through defines located in ptplib.c. Parameters
00478         that directly derive from the 1588v2 specification site
00479         the relevant section numbers.
00480 
00481 Configuration flags for ptplib_initialize:
00482 
00483     - PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_PEER_DELAY
00484         - Use peer to peer versus normal delay messages.
00485     - PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_MULTICAST
00486         - Use multicast announce and sync. Otherwise messages
00487         are unicast to the respective clock.
00488     - PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_UNICAST
00489         - Use unicast whenever possible. The 1588v2 protocol
00490         dictates that all messages use multicast addresses even
00491         when directed at a specific host. This flag changes this
00492         behavior to use unicast messages for all messages destine
00493         to a single host. Messages sent to multiple host still
00494         use multicast.
00495     - PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_FREQUENCY_ADJUST
00496         - Adjust the frequency of the clock. Without this flag the
00497         local clock frequency will be monitored but not adjusted.
00498     - PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_PHASE_ADJUST
00499         - Adjust the phase of the local clock. Without this flag
00500         the local will not be adjusted to match 1588v2 time. The
00501         only time you would not want this flag is when you are
00502         using the Telecom extension and only adjusting clock
00503         frequency. Delay messages will only be sent if
00504         PTPLIB_FLAGS_USE_PHASE_ADJUST is used.
00505 
00506 
00507 @subsection ptp_daemon 3.6. ptp-1588v2, the Linux userspace Daemon
00508 
00509 @b TBD
00510 
00511 @verbatim
00512 Usage:
00513 ./ptp-1588v2 interface[:transport] [interface[:transport]]*
00514 
00515     interface = Linux network device name (eth0, eth1, etc).
00516     transport = Which transport to use (802.3, UDP). Defaults to 802.3.
00517 
00518 @endverbatim
00519 
00520 @section ptp_version1 4. PTPv1 - IEEE 1588-2004
00521 
00522 Cavium Network's implementation of IEEE1588-2004 is based on the opensource
00523 project PTPd. From the web page (http://ptpd.sourceforge.net/), here
00524 is a description  of PTPd:
00525 
00526 @verbatim
00527 The PTP daemon (PTPd) implements the Precision Time protocol (PTP) as
00528 defined by the IEEE 1588 standard.  PTP was developed to provide very
00529 precise time coordination of LAN connected computers.
00530 
00531 PTPd is a complete implementation of the IEEE 1588 specification for a
00532 standard (non-boundary) clock.  PTPd has been tested with and is known
00533 to work properly with other IEEE 1588 implementations.  The source
00534 code for PTPd is freely available under a BSD-style license.  Thanks
00535 to contributions from users, PTPd is becoming an increasingly
00536 portable, interoperable, and stable IEEE 1588 implementation.
00537 
00538 PTPd can run on most 32-bit little- or big-endian processors.  It does
00539 not require an FPU, so it is great for embedded processors.  PTPd
00540 currently runs on Linux, uClinux, FreeBSD, and NetBSD.  It should also
00541 be easy to port to other platforms.
00542 
00543 PTPd is free. Everyone is welcome to use and contribute to PTPd.
00544 @endverbatim
00545 
00546 PTPd is part of the Linux filesystem supplied as part of the OCTEON
00547 SDK.  The source code can be found under
00548 @b linux/embedded_rootfs/storage/ptpd-1.0.0.tar.gz.  Cavium used the
00549 opensource PTPd version 1.0 with a single source patch.  This patch
00550 allows PTPd to be compiled using the Cavium GCC compiler, which is
00551 much newer than the one used by the PTPd project.  This patch can be
00552 found in the same directory with a filename of ptpd-fix-limits.patch.
00553 
00554 */
